Description: Terracotta figure fragment of horse and rider. The horse's mane is indicated with incised lines. Handmade and hollow. Made of fine light red-brown fabric with buff surfaces and a grey core.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

A small numner of hollow, handmade terracottas of horses or cavalry figures in an East Greek fabric were found in Naukratis (British Museum GR2011,5009.290-5; Oxford AN1896-1908-E.4672). Parallel from Kamirus, Rhodes, dated to the late 6th century BC also hollow and handmade construction (Higgins 1970, no. 104 riding 'ram'?, see also 6th century BC Halicarnassus nos. 301- 23). Handmade simple horse figurines are common in the Archaic and Cypro-Archaic periods of Greece and Cyprus. Parallels from Kamiros, Rhodes (Jacopi 1930, figs. 110 and 323). Jacopi, G. 1930. Esplorazione archeologica di Camiro I. Clara Rhodos IV. Scavi Nelle Necropoli Camiresi 1929-1930.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DA.122) (Phase 3)
